sec.p: Review

Saponins of
Agave
: Chemistry and bioactivity
Jasmeen Sidana * , Bikram Singh, Om P. Sharma
Natural Product Chemistry and Process Development Division, CSIR-Institute of Himalayan Bioresource Technology, Palampur, 176 061, Himachal Pradesh , India
A R T I C L E I N F o
Article history:
Received 27 February 2016 Received in revised form
15 June 2016
Accepted 23 June 2016 Available online 30 June 2016

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Saponins
Sapogenins
Spirostanol glycosides Furostanol glycosides
A B S T R A C T

The genus
Agave
comprises more than 400 species with geographical presence in the tropical and sub-tropical regions of the world. These plants have a rich history of folkloric use and are known for a wide spectrum of applications. Secondary metabolites of diverse chemical classes have been reported from
Agave species.
Owing to their pharmacological significance, the steroidal saponins of
Agave
have caught the attention of phytochemists, biologists and drug discovery scientists. The present review describes 141 steroidal saponins and sapogenins and covers the literature published from 1970 to 2015. It is a comprehensive and coherent presentation of the structures, methods of chemical profiling, structure elucidation and biological activities of the saponins and sapogenins reported from
Agave
. The article provides a perspective of the research on steroidal compounds of
Agave
.
2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
The earliest report of the saponins of
Agave
was in the year 1932 (
). Furthermore,
Agave
was recognized as a new and potential source of steroidal sapogenins (
,
). Till now, more than 50 species of
Agave
have been investigated for their saponin and sapogenin constituents. An earlier review gave an overview of the phytochemistry of Agavaceae family (
). It included some of the sapogenins and saponins of
Agave
,
Cordyline
,
Dracaena
,
Furcraea
,
Nolina
,
Sansevieria
and
Yucca
. However, it did not discuss the extraction, isolation, chemical profiling and structure elucidation of these compounds. Another review on the traditional products of
Agave species
focused on food and nutraceutical products of
Agave
and medicinal properties of the extracts and compounds isolated from this genus (
).
recently reviewed the phenols of
Agave
and compiled details of occurrence of phenols and flavonoids in the different species of
Agave
, as well as the intra- and inter-specific variability in the phenolic profiles and chemotaxonomic importance of the phenolics in this genus (
).

sec.title:
2. Natural products from
Agave species
2.1. Sapogenins
sec.p:
Agave
is an important source of steroidal sapogenins of the spirostanol-type (
1
27
) whereas Agavegenin D ( 28 ) is the only cholestane-type sapogenin reported from
Agave
. Sapogenins with furostanol and furospirostanol skeleta have not been discovered in this genus yet. Spirostanols are biogenetically derived from cholestane and are 16,22; 22,26-bisepoxycholestanes (
). The spirostanol skeleton has a tetrahydrofuran ring (E) and a tetrahydropyran ring (F) joined at C- 22 in a spiran fashion. These compounds are isolated from leaves, flowers, leaf juice, rhizomes and callus cultures of
Agave plants
. Spirostan sapogenins of
Agave
differ from each other in terms of a) the configuration and number of the hydroxyl moieties attached to the parent nucleus, b) presence or absence of carbonyl group at C-12, c) presence or absence of unsaturation in rings B or C and d) configuration of H at C-5 and -25 (due to biogenetic differences) (Agrawal et al., 1985, 1995). Table 1 and Fig. 1 present the sapogenins reported from the genus
Agave
.

sec.title: 2.2. Saponins
sec.p:
A saponin molecule is typically comprised of an aglycone (hydrophobic, sapogenin) and a sugar (hydrophilic, glycone) unit. Sugar moieties present in the
Agave
saponins include b -D-glucopyranosyl, b -D-galactopyranosyl, b -D-xylopyranosyl and
a -
Lrhamnopyranosyls moieties. On the basis of the sapogenin nucleus present, saponins of
Agave
can be broadly classified as spirostanol glycosides and furostanol glycosides (Agrawal et al., 1985, 1995). These compounds, depending on the number of sugars attached, may further be classified as mono-, di-, tri-, tetra-, penta- or hexaglycosides. If the sugar (or sugar chain) is present at only one position of the sapogenin, the saponin is called monodesmosidic (
). The majority of spirostanol saponins of
Agave
is monodesmosidic and have sugar unit present at C-3 of the aglycone ( Table 2 ). Bidesmosidic saponins, on the other hand, have two sugar units located at two different points of the aglycone nucleus (
). Bidesmosidic spirostanol saponins are relatively scarce in
Agave plants
, with only a few being reported till date. However, a good number of bidesmosidic furostanol glycosides are found in this genus ( Table 3 ). The forthcoming subsections discuss the structure, occurrence, chemistry and bioactivities of the spirostanol and furostanol glycosides of
Agave
.
2.2.1. Spirostanol glycosides

The majority of the spirostanol glycosides reported from
Agave
have trans , trans and cis geometry for B/C, C/D and D/E rings, respectively. However, rings A/B can either be trans or cis fused leading to either an a - or b -hydrogen at position 5. The 21-methyl group is a -oriented and the spiro -carbon atom (C-22) is present in its R configuration. The 27-methyl group can either be equatorial ( a ) or axial ( b ) leading to 25 R or 25 S -configurations, respectively.

In spirostanol monoglycosides (
29
35
), the b -D-glucopyranoside is the sugar moiety present in most cases. Compounds 31 , 32 and 35 have a free 3-hydroxyl moiety and the sugar is attached through a 6-hydroxyl group in 31 and 32 and through a 24- hydroxyl in 35 ( Fig. 2 ). Monodesmosidic spirostanol diglycosides (
43
50
) have b -D-galactopyranoside as the inner monosaccharide and a - or b -D-glucopyranoside as the terminal monosaccharide. However, bidesmosidic spirostanol diglycosides (
37
42
) invariably possess b -D-glucopyranoside as their sugar moieties. Compounds
37
41
have glycosylated hydroxyl groups at positions 3 and 6. In 42 , both 6- and 24-hydroxyls are glycosylated, while the 3-hydroxyl moiety is free. It is notable that glycosylation at positions other than 3 are only observed in the case of mono- and di-glycosides of sapogenins. Structures of spirostanol glycosides are presented in
Figs. 3
7
. Table 2 also gives the occurrence and bioactivities of spirostanol glycosides reported from
Agave
.
2.2.2. Furostanol glycosides

Furostanol glycosides are 16,22-epoxycholestane derivatives and have a pentacyclic skeleton. Most of the furostanol saponins of
Agave
are bidesmosidic and are 3- and 26- O -glycosides ( Fig. 8 ). The monosaccharide present at the position 26 is invariably b -D-glucopyranoside. Compounds 118 and 119 are tridesmosidic and are glycosylated at C-3, -6 and -26.

sec.title: 3.2. Chemical pro fi ling
sec.p: Saponins and sapogenins are analyzed in natural matrices viz. leaves, leaf juice, coffee grounds (sapogenin concentrates) and callus cultures of plants using different methodologies. Some of these methods are TLC, high-performance thin layer chromatography (HPTLC), gas (liquid) chromatography (GLC or GC) and HPLC.

Both spirostanol and furostanol glycosides stain yellow when the TLC is derivatized with 1% anisaldehyde and 10% sulfuric acid in methanol. While furostanol glycosides stain red with 1% dimethylaminobenzaldehyde with 10% hydrochloric acid in ethanol (Ehrlich reagent) spirostanol glycosides are colorless (
).
continued
on
next
page

have developed an HPTLC method for the determination of hecogenin ( 1 ) in the leaf powder of
Agave americana
. The mobile phase used for the analysis was toluene/ ethyl acetate/methanol (6:1:0.8). Derivatization of the analytes was done with anisaldehyde-sulfuric acid reagent followed by heating of the TLC plate for 3 min at 100 C . The yellow band corresponding to hecogenin ( 1 ) was densitometrically quantified at 430 nm . This simple, sensitive and accurate method can be routinely used for quality control of
A. americana
plant material (
). Similar research reported the simultaneous quantitation of hecogenin ( 1 ), kammogenin ( 8 ) and manogenin ( 4 ) in the extracts of
Agave amaniensis ( Indrayanto et al., 1994 )
.

sec.title: 4. Structure elucidation
4.1. Spectroscopic methods
sec.p:
Sapogenins may be readily identified on the basis of their TLC, IR, MS, 1 H and 13 C NMR data. A careful comparison of the spectroscopic data of sapogenins with literature reports can lead to unambiguous identification of them (
). However, in cases where a detailed analysis of the structure is required, 1D and 2D NMR techniques are needed ( Fig. S1 ).
4.1.1. IR spectroscopy

The spiroketal moiety of the spirostanol sapogenins and saponins is readily characterized by IR absorptions at 980, 915, 898 and 862 cm 1 . If the 898 cm 1 band is intense, as compared to the 915 cm 1 band, it indicates a R -configuration of the 25-methyl group. The absorption band near 1700 cm 1 also indicates the presence of a keto functionality, and hydroxyl groups have absorption bands near 3420 and 1046 cm 1 (
).
4.1.2. Mass spectrometry

Different types of mass spectroscopic experiments have been used in the recent past for the structure elucidation of saponins, with the most common being High Resolution Mass Spectrometry (HRMS). Electron Spray Ionization (ESI) with time-of-flight (TOF) detection and Fast Atom Bombardment (FAB) are the commonly used ionization techniques. Both negative as well as positive ion modes have been used to obtain the molecular weight of saponins.
4.1.3. NMR spectroscopy

Most of the saponins of
Agave
have four methyl resonances in the 1 H and 13 C NMR spectra. These signals may be distinguished into two tertiary ( CH 3 -18 and 19) and two secondary methyls ( CH 3 -21 and 27) in most cases. The tertiary methyls are always b - oriented and are present at the ring junctions of C/D and A/B, respectively. The 21-methyl group is a -oriented and establishes a S - configuration for C-20. Compound 40 , however, is an exception to this general observation as the presence of a b -hydroxyl at C-20 renders the CH 3 -21 moiety tertiary and an R -configuration for C-20 (
). The 27-methyl group may either be a - or b -oriented leading to R- or S- stereochemistries at C-25.

4.1.3.1. Ring fusion type .
The fusion between the rings of the steroidal nucleus determines the orientation of the substituents present at the respective junctions. All steroidal sapogenins/saponins reported from
Agave
have a trans -fusion between rings B/C and C/D, and a cis -fusion between rings D/E. The A/B rings may have a cis- or trans- fusion and, therefore, structure elucidation of sapogenins/ saponins of
Agave
requires determination of the A/B ring junction. The trans- and cis- A/B fusions lead to a - and b -oriented 5-H, respectively. The 1 H and 13 C NMR chemical shifts of C/H-3, -5, -9 and -19 can be significantly influenced by the type of ring fusion (Agrawal, 2003; Agrawal et al., 1998). For example, an a -oriented H- 5 resonates at the d 0.78, and its corresponding carbon appears at d 44.6. However, the b -oriented 5-H is observed at d 2.02, with the C-5 appearing at 36.6.

4.1.3.2. Stereochemistry at C-25. Steroidal sapogenins and saponins occur as 25 R- and 25 S- stereoisomers and are characterized by equatorial ( a -oriented) and axial ( b -oriented) 27-methyl groups, respectively. Agrawal (2003, 2004) has derived empirical rules based on 1 H NMR spectroscopic analysis for determination of 25 R- / 25 S- stereochemistry of these compounds. In the case of 25 S - compounds having a spirostanol skeleton, the geminal protons of ring F viz. H 2 -23, -24 and 26 are more resolved and the difference between the chemical shifts of the two protons is > 0.35 ppm. This difference, in 25 R -spirostanol glycosides, is usually < 0.20 ppm. For furostanol glycosides, the difference between the chemical shifts of the geminal H 2 -26 is < 0.48 for 25 R - and > 0.57 for 25 S- configuration (Agrawal, 2003, 2004). Table S1 shows chemical shifts of geminal protons of the ring F of steroidal sapogenins and saponins reported from
Agave
. It is noteworthy here that chemical shifts of H 2 -23 and H
2 -24 in
25 S -spirostanol glycosides are much more resolved as compared to 25 R -spirostanol glycosides. Chemical shifts of H 2 -26 show distinctive values that are conclusive of a 25 R / S -configuration. For example, in the case of 25 R -spirostanol glycosides, the difference between the chemical shifts of the H 2 -26 geminal protons ranges from 0.06 to 0.12 ppm. The same difference, in 25 S -spirostanol glycosides, is from 0.67 to 0.71 ppm. For furostanol glycosides, the chemical shift difference between the geminal H 2 -26 is
0.32
0.34 in
the 25 R - and 0.59 in the 25 S - configurations.

4.1.3.4. Unsaturation. Several unsaturated sapogenins and saponins have been reported from
Agave
. However, olefinic bonds are very typical, in that they are present at the position- 5 in the majority of cases ( 7 , 8 ,
22
24
,
69
72
,
92
95
,
99
102
,
127
128
, 130 ,
133
136
and 139 ). This double bond results in appearance of carbon resonances at d 139.5 to 141.2 (C-5) and 121.2 to 122.1 (C-6). Further, the presence of the double bond can be ascertained by a one proton signal at d 5.22 to 5.35 appearing as a broad singlet, doublet or multiplet. The 1 H and 13 C chemical shifts of this double bond are completely unaffected by hydroxyl substitutions in ring A (
;
), 12-oxo group (
,
), glycosylation at C-10 (Abdel-Gawad et al., 1999) or even the type of sapogenin skeleton (i.e. furostan or spirostan) (Abdel-Gawad et al., 1999;
;
;
).

Saponins with a
25(27) are relatively uncommon in
Agave
. However, compound 72 was isolated from leaves of
Agave decipiens
and it has a spirostan skeleton glycosylated at position 10. It also has two double bonds at
5 and
25(27) . The olefinic resonances at C-25 and -27 were identified by d 143.3 (C) and d 108.6 ( CH 2 ). The exocyclic methylene depicted by proton signals at d 4.81, 4.78 (H 2 - 27), along with corresponding carbon signals is characteristic of
25(27) unsaturation (Abdel-Gawad et al., 1999). Fig. S4 shows the positions of the olefinic bonds as found in the saponins of
Agave
. The chemical shift ranges of the protons and carbons involved in the double bonds are also presented. 4.1.3.5. Hydroxyl substituents. Hydroxyl substituents are generally present at positions 2, 3 and 6 in saponins of
Agave
. In case of spirostanol glycosides, hydroxyl groups have also been encountered at C-23 and rarely at either C-12 ( 70 ) or C-20 ( 40 ). In furostanol glycosides of
Agave
, C-12, -20 and 23 hydroxyls have not been observed so far. However, a C-22 hydroxyl (or methoxyl) is invariably present.

4.1.3.6. Sugar moieties. The complete identification of the sugar units present in saponins involves determination of 1) number and identification of sugars, 2) sequence of sugars and 3) linkage of sugar or sugar chain to the aglycone.

The linkage between monosaccharides of the sugar chain can be deduced from the 13 C NMR chemical shifts. Non-anomeric carbons involved in a glycosidic linkage show a substantial downfield shift in comparison to unsubstituted carbons. These glycosylation shifts are used to determine the points of linkages between two consecutive monosaccharides in an oligosaccharide unit of saponins. The terminal monosaccharide can be indicated by the absence of any glycosylation shift. Table S2 summarises glycosylation shifts of various b -D-glucopyranosyl moieties commonly found in saponins of
Agave
. Although these data are not exhaustive, and are based on a small number of examples, they indicate the patterns of downfield shifts in 13 C NMR signals of carbons involved in glycosidic bonds. Final assignments of the protons and carbons in the oligosaccharide unit were based on the correlations in HSQC and HSQC-TOCSY spectra. The sequence of sugar chains was established by HMBC/ROESY experiments.

sec.title: 4.2. Chemical methods
5. Biological activities
5.1. Hemolytic activity
5.2. Cytotoxicity
sec.p:
Conventionally, the brine shrimp (
Artemia salina
) lethality assay has been used to study the cytotoxicity of natural compounds and extracts (
). The ethanolic and aqueous extracts of the leaves of
Agave cantala
were tested for their lethality against brine shrimps. The 50% lethal concentration (LC 50 ) of the alcoholic and aqueous extracts was 12.5 and 15.0 mg/mL, respectively (
). In the same assay, the LC 50 of the aqueous extract of the leaves of
Agave intermixta
L. was 345.22 mg / mL. The aqueous extract of
A. intermixta
L. was further evaluated for its antimitotic activity in
Allium cepa
root meristematic cells. A complete inhibition of the cell division was observed after 24 h treatment. However, no chromosomal abnormalities were observed in the cells. This extract also exhibited a cytostatic activity on HEp-2 cells with an IC 50 of 68.0
g/mL (
). The methanol extract of the leaves of
A. americana
showed an IC 50 of 826.1
g/mL against Human MCF-7 breast carcinoma cells and an IC 50 of 8.455
g/mL against VERO (African green monkey kidney cell line) in MTT assay (
).

sec.title: 5.3. Antiin fl ammatory activity
5.4. Antihyperalgesic activity
5.5. Gastroprotective activity
5.6. Antioxidant activity
sec.p:
have investigated the antioxidant activity of six
Agave species
growing in Mexico . The wild species included
A. rzedowskiana
,
A. impressa
,
A. ornithobroma
and
A. schidigera
and the cultivated species was
A. tequilana
.
A. rzedowskiana
showed the highest antioxidant activity (27.41
M of Trolox equivalents per gram of dry weight) in DPPH assay (
). Ethanolic extract of leaves of
A. sisalana
showed a weak inhibition of xanthine oxidase, tyrosinase and lipoxygenase (
).

sec.title: 5.7. Antimicrobial activity
sec.p:
Antimicrobial activity of crude extracts of different
Agave species
was done using disc-diffusion or well-diffusion methods (
;
;
;
). The saponin-rich methanol and aqueous extracts of
A. sisalana
were evaluated for their antimicrobial potential. The minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of both extracts against
Staphylococcus aureus
,
Salmonella typhi
,
Escherichia coli
,
Streptococcus pyogenes
and
Candida albicans
ranged from 10 to 20 mg /mL (
). The methanol extract of the leaves of
Agave attenuata
showed a strong inhibitory activity against
Aspergillus fl avus
and
Alternaria alternata
with MIC values of 18.4 and 69.4 mg /mL, respectively. The chloroform fraction of this extract also showed strong inhibition of
Rhizoctonia solani
and
A. fl avus
with MIC of 20.4 and 25.1 mg /mL, respectively. The n - butanol fraction of the same extract inhibited
Escherichia coli
with an MIC of 15.2 mg /mL (
).

Ethanolic extracts of the leaves of
Agave lecheguilla
,
A. picta
,
A. scabra
and
A. lophantha
were tested for their antimicrobial activity against several bacterial (
E. coli
,
S. aureus
,
Listeria monocytogenes
,
Vibrio cholerae
,
Bacillus cereus
and
Yersinia enterocolitica
) and fungal (
Cryptococcus neoformans
,
Microsporum gypseum
,
Trichophyton tonsurans
and
Sporotrix schenckii
) species. In the antibacterial assay, the extract of
A. picta
inhibited growth of
E. coli
,
S. aureus L. monocytogenes
and
V. cholera
significantly. However, the other extracts were not active. All four
Agave
extracts were active against the tested fungal species (
). Similar studies established the antimicrobial potential of extracts of
A. lecheguilla
,
A. rzedowskiana
,
A. impressa
,
A. ornithobroma
,
A. schidigera
,
A. tequilana
and
A. sisalana
(
;
;
).

have also evaluated the antifungal activity of 28 steroidal compounds, including 6 sapogenins and 12 saponins reported from
Agave species.
The results of this study revealed that all the sapogenins were inactive up to a concentration of 20
g/mL. Amongst the saponins, the compounds 96 and 98 (with tigogenin ( 13 ) as aglycone) () showed significant activity against
C. neoformans
. Antifungal activity was associated with individual aglycones, as well as the composition of the sugar chains (
).

The antifungal efficacy of
Agave plants
was also evaluated against the fungal pathogens of crops. The methanolic leaf extract of
A. americana
showed antifungal activity against
Alternaria brassicae
and inhibited conidial germination of the fungus (
). Similarly, aqueous extracts of bulbs of
A. lechuguilla
inhibited
Fusarium oxysporum
, a fungal pathogen of tomato (
).

sec.title: 5.8. Phytotoxicity
sec.p:
The ethanol-water (7:3) extract of
Agave offoyana
leaves was evaluated for its phytotoxic potential. The standard target species included
Lactuca sativa
L.,
Lycopersicum esculentum
L.,
Lepidium sativum
L. and
Allium cepa L. Some
sub-fractions of the ethanol-water extract inhibited the root growth of target species signifi- cantly and were more active as compared to Logran
, a commercial herbicide. Phytotoxicity assessment of pure compounds revealed that the sugar chain at C-3 of the sapogenin (aglycone) affected the bioactivity. Compound with five sugar units ( 101 ) had a better inhibition profile, as compared to the compound with four sugar units ( 71 ). Also, b -D-xylopyranosyl moiety (instead of OE -L-rhamnopyranosyl) at the end of the glycosidic chain increased the phytotoxicity slightly (as shown by comparison of compounds 93 , IC 50 101.4
M) and 100 , IC 50 90.4
M). No difference in activity was found between the spirostane- and furostane-type of the sapogenin nucleus (
,
).

sec.title: 5.9. Molluscicidal activity
sec.p:
The crude ethanolic extract of
A. cantala
was lethal against
Biomphalaria glabrata
(vector of schistosomiasis) at a concentration of 25 ppm and compound 77 purified from this extract showed activity at 10 ppm over 24 h (
). The ethanolic extracts of the fresh leaves of
A. attenuata
and
A. sisalana
were tested for their molluscicidal activity against
Biomphlaria alexandrina
. The LC 50 for both extracts after 72 h was 82 and 101 mg /L, respectively. A notable increase in the glutathione, glutathione peroxidase, glutathione reductase, glutathione S -transferase, catalase and
-glutamyl transferase was observed in snails exposed to high concentrations of
A. attenuata
extract. These enzymes were concluded to be responsible for protection of the snail in the presence of molluscicidal agents (
).

sec.title: 6. Conclusion and future areas of research
sec.p:
The present review gave a summary of the saponins of
Agave
, their extraction, isolation and profiling methods, structure elucidation strategies and biological activities. The first and second sections of this article gave an overview of
Agave
and the saponins reported from this genus.

Agave
contains, primarily, steroidal sapogenins and saponins (
Tables 1
3
). Of the four known skeletons of steroidal saponins, two viz. spirostanols and furostanols are abundantly found in
Agave
(
Figs. 2
8
). Saponins having carboxylic moieties in the algycone and sugar(s) are not found in this genus.
Agave
saponins have typical glycosylation pattern with b -D-galactopyranose as the sugar directly attached to the aglycone in majority of the cases (
Figs. 3
8
). a -L-Rhamnopyranose is not observed in the saponins with one and two sugars. It is present in higher saccharides (
Figs. 6
7
); however, it is never linked directly to the aglycone moiety (
and
;
).

Steroidal saponins constitute a group of compounds with varied structural and biological properties. The biological significance of these compounds calls for the need of elaboration of suitable extraction methods and isolation strategies. The third section of this article presented an up-to-date review of the methods of extraction, isolation and chemical profiling of the
Agave
saponins. The developments in the methods of extraction and chemical profiling of
Agave
saponins are rather slow. Classical methods viz. Soxhlet extraction and maceration were used in majority of the cases. However, other less time-consuming and greener methods such as ultra-sound assisted extraction, microwave-assisted extraction, super-critical fluid extraction and accelerated solvent extraction could increase the overall efficiency of the extraction procedures (
). Similarly, modern methods of analysis such as LC-MS and other hyphenated techniques may be of use in the analysis and structure elucidation of these compounds (
).

The section on structure elucidation described spectroscopic, as well as chemical methods. Chemical methods have been superseded by the spectroscopic techniques, such as 2D-NMR and highresolution mass spectroscopy. However, hydrolysis and methylation techniques are still used for of complex saponins. NMR methods were also employed to establish the overall structure, as well as the stereochemistries of
Agave
saponins. With the advent of solvent suppression tools, such as DOSY, it is now possible to determine saponin structures in mixtures (
).

Various biological and pharmacological activities of
Agave plants
and their products have also been summarized. A number of bioactivities were attributed to saponins of
Agave
( Tables 2 and 3 ). The long history of human use, favorable pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic profiles and varied spectrum of bio-activities make
Agave
products attractive and safe candidates for therapeutic use (
). Substantial progress in the bioactivity evaluation and establishment of mechanisms of action of the isolated
Agave
compounds ( Tables 2 and 3 ) has paved the way for new product development. Currently, there is a shift from a single to a multiple target approach in drug discovery (
). Future studies need to have a focus on structure activity relationships (SAR) of pure bioactive molecules of
Agave
isolated for strategic drug discovery leads and translational research for clinical applications (
). Molecular modeling studies may also prove helpful in the preliminary evaluation and establishment of SAR (
). A vast reservoir of
Agave spp.
remains untapped in terms of Phytochemistry, as well as pharmacology, and this is an area for future studies.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Dr. Jasmeen Sidana is a post-doctoral researcher at the CSIR-Institute of Himalayan Bioresource Technology, Palampur, India . She received her B. Pharm. from Punjabi University, Patiala, India . She earned her M.S. (Pharmacy) and Ph.D. in Natural Products from the National Institute of Pharmaceutical Education and Research (NIPER), SAS Nagar, Punjab , India . At NIPER, she studied the isolation, structure elucidation and chemo-profiling of natural products with special reference to formylated phloroglucinols. Her present research focuses on chemical profiling and bioactivity of saponin-bearing plants of the western Himalayas.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Dr. Om Sharma is Emeritus Scientist at CSIR - Institute of Himalayan Bioresource Technology, Palampur, India . Dr.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Sharma earned his PhD in Biochemistry at Central Drug Research Institute, Lucknow, India . Thereafter, he joined Agricultural Research Service and has served in different capacities in IVRI since 1977. Dr. Sharma has an experience of 41 years in research and teaching and has published 1126 research papers and review articles. He has won Commonwealth Postdoctoral fellowship at the University of West London, Brunel (1984
1985); Gold Medal of Panjab University, Chandigarh ; Best Paper Awards of the Society of Biological Chemists ( India ) on two occasions and of the Society of Toxicology ( India ). Dr. Sharma is a Fellow of the Society of Toxicology ( India ), is a life member of Indian Science Congress Association, Society of Biological Chemists, and Society of Toxicology. Dr. Sharma has worked extensively and published in the areas of free radical biochemistry, plant toxins, plant secondary metabolites, and natural products in relation to animal toxicity (biochemistry, disposition, mechanisms). The current focus of his research is modulation of rumen function using plant secondary metabolites and isolation, profiling and biological activity evaluation of plant saponins.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Dr. Bikram Singh has completed his Ph.D at CIMAP (1982
1987). After completion of his doctoral studies, he joined CSIR-IHBT on 1988 as Junior Scientist. During his tenure, he has visited Hannover, Germany under CSIR- DAAD, Bilateral Exchange and Rothamsted International, U.K. He has worked on the isolation and characterization of biologically important natural products and developed several analytical methods for their quantification. Presently, he is appointed as Senior Principal Scientist at CSIR-IHBT, Palampur, India and is working on the value addition of naturally occurring molecules along with the development of new catalytic methodologies for important transformations by using metal phthalocyanine as catalyst. He has 137 publications and nine patents to his credit. He has guided eight PhD students, two MPhil and fifteen MSc students. Presently eight students are doing PhD under his guidance.
